item.description:
Networking Fundamentals

Network & Internet

  • A network of network ğŸ”¢
    • roughly hierarchical
    • at center: “tier-1” ISPs ğŸŒŸ
      • Verizon, CenturyLink, AT&T ğŸ“¡
      • national/international coverage ğŸŒ
    • Interconnected by routersé€šè¿‡è·¯ç”±å™¨äº’ç›¸è¿æ¥ ğŸ”„
      • Tier-1 providers interconnect (peer) privately å¯¹ç­‰äº’è” ğŸ”’
      • Tier-1 providers also interconnect at public network access points (NAPs) å…¬å…±ç½‘ç»œæ¥å…¥ç‚¹ ğŸ“
    • “Tier-2” ISPs: smaller (often regional) ğŸŒ
      • Comcast ğŸ–¥ï¸
    • Connect to one or more tier-1 ISPs, possibly other tier-2 ISPs ğŸ”Œ
      • Tier-2 ISP pays tier-1 ISP for connectivity to rest of Internet ğŸ’¸
      • Tier-2 ISP is customer of tier-1 provider. ğŸ§‘â€ğŸ’»
      • Tier-2 ISPs also peer privately with each other, interconnect at NAP ğŸ”
    • “Tier-3” ISPs and local ISPs ğŸ“¶
      • last hop (“access”) network (closest to end systems) ğŸ“
      • Local and tier-3 ISPs are customers of higher tier ISPs connecting them to rest of Internet ğŸ› ï¸

local ISP â†’ Tier 3 ISP â†’ Tier-2 ISP â†’ Tier 1 ISP â†’ Tier 1 ISP â†’ Tier-2 ISP â†’ local ISP ğŸ”„

Network Performance Metrics

Bandwidth (capacity) / Throughput ååé‡ (actual)

  • data transmitted per time unit â±ï¸
  • Notation: bps = bits per second âš¡
  • Network speed test ğŸ–¥ï¸

Latency (delay) æ—¶å»¶

  • time to send message from point A to point B ğŸ›£ï¸
  • one-way versus round-trip time (RTT) ğŸ”„
  • $$Latency = Propagation + Transmit + Queue$$
  • $$Propagation = \frac{Distance}{propagation\ speed\ in\ medium (\sim 2\times10^{8}\ m/sec)}$$
  • $$Transmit = \frac{Size}{Bandwidth}$$

Availability

  • Percent of time the network is available to users for transmission and reception â²ï¸
  • Want 24x7x365 availability ğŸ•“
  • Telephone network: Five 9s (99.999%) ğŸ“

Error Rate

  • Percent of lost or damaged messages or bits ğŸ›‘

Network Structural Models

Client/Server

å®¢æˆ·æœº/æœåŠ¡å™¨æ¨¡å¼

  • server:
    • always-on host å§‹ç»ˆå¤„äºè¿è¡ŒçŠ¶æ€çš„ä¸»æœº
    • permanent IP address å›ºå®šçš„ IP åœ°å€
    • server farms for scaling ç”¨äºæ‰©å±•è§„æ¨¡çš„æœåŠ¡å™¨é›†ç¾¤
  • clients:
    • communicate with server ä¸æœåŠ¡å™¨è¿›è¡Œé€šä¿¡
    • may be intermittently connected å¯èƒ½æ˜¯é—´æ­‡æ€§è¿æ¥
    • may have dynamic IP addresses
    • do not communicate directly with each other

Peer-to-Peer

å¯¹ç­‰ç½‘ç»œæ¨¡å¼

  • no alwaye-on server ä¸å­˜åœ¨å§‹ç»ˆåœ¨çº¿çš„æœåŠ¡å™¨
  • arbitrary end systems directly communicate
  • peers are intermittently connected and change IP addresses
  • Example :
    • Gnutella
    • Blockchain!
  • Highly scalable but difficult to manage å¯æ‰©å±•æ€§æå¼ºï¼Œä½†éš¾ä»¥ç®¡ç†

Hybrid of Client-Server and P2P

  • Instant messaging / Skype
    • Client-client connection is direct (not through server)
    • Presence detection/location centralized:
      • User registers its IP address with central server when it comes online.
      • User contacts central server to find IP addresses of buddies.

The clients and Cloud Computing

  • The thin client has a limited processing power, memory or storage âš™ï¸
  • Applications run on the web, in a “cloud” â˜ï¸
    • Amazon offers basic services: storage, basic computing elements ğŸ”‘
    • Google offers more advanced services: word processors, spreadsheets ğŸ“
    • IBM offers Blue Cloud â˜ï¸

Protocols

  • Conventions and rules governing this interaction are specified by the Layer N Protocol
    • A protocol is an agreement about how communications are to proceed ğŸ“œ
    • Without a protocol communication can be difficult or even impossible ğŸš«
    • Telephone conversation, Postal addresses ğŸ“âœ‰ï¸

Division of Protocols

  • Connection-Oriented é¢å‘è¿æ¥çš„ ğŸ”—
    • a logical connection be established between two devices before transferring data ğŸ”„
    • a circuit is not a prerequisite for a connection âš¡
    • Circuit-switched => connection-oriented, but not all connection-oriented => circuit switching ğŸ› ï¸
  • Connectionless ğŸš«
    • do not establish a connection between devices ğŸ”“

Packet Switching åˆ†ç»„äº¤æ¢

  1. Break message into smaller packets (or frames) ğŸ“¬
  2. Route packets individually; Packet switches along the way make decisions about the packet ğŸ”„

Netwrok Architecture - A Layered Model

Needs for A Layered Model

  • Task broken into subtasks ğŸ› ï¸
    • Implemented separately in layers in stack
  • Each layer provides a service to the layer above â¬†ï¸
  • Each layer hides details of how the service is provided from the layer above ğŸ•µï¸â€â™‚ï¸
  • Functions needed in both systems ğŸ”„
  • The Nth layer on one machine “talks to” or interacts with the Nth layer on another machine ğŸ“¡

Protocols and Network Architecture

Encapsulation ğŸ“¨

  • Addition of Control Information to Data
    • Address Information ğŸ“
    • Error-detecting Code ğŸ”
    • Protocol Control ğŸ›¡ï¸
      $$ \text{N-layer PDU (Protocol Data Unit)} = \text{Header} + \text{(N+1)-layer PDU} + \text{Trailer} $$

Network Architecture

  • The set of protocols and layers together make up the Network Architecture ğŸŒ
    • A Network Architecture Specification must provide enough information to allow implementation in hardware/software ğŸ’»
    • Implementation specific details are not part of the architecture and should be irrelevant for inter-operation ğŸ”’
    • With one protocol per layer we have a Protocol Stack ğŸ—ï¸

Standardized Network Architectures

  • Required for devices to communicate ğŸ—£ï¸
  • Vendors have more marketable products ğŸ’¼
  • Customers can insist on standards based equipment ğŸ“Š
  • Two standards:
    • OSI Reference model
      • Never lived up to early promises âŒ
    • TCP/IP protocol suite
      • Most widely used ğŸŒ
      • De facto âœ…

Standards

OSI

  • Open Systems Interconnection
  • Developed by the International Organization for Standardization (ISO) ğŸŒ
  • Seven Layers 7ï¸âƒ£
  • A Theoretical System Delivered Too Late! ğŸ•°ï¸
  • TCP/IP Is the De Facto Standard ğŸ†

OSI Layers

  • Application ——— Acronyms ğŸ“–
  • Presentation —— Pointless â“
  • Session ———— Students ğŸ‘©â€ğŸ«
  • Transport ——— Teach ğŸšš
  • Network ———— Not ğŸš«
  • Data Link ———— Do ğŸ’¡
  • Physical ———— Please ğŸ™

OSI Layers (1)

  • Physical
    • Physical Interface Between Devices âš™ï¸
      • Mechanical â€“ hardware, topology ğŸ—ï¸
      • Electrical - signaling âš¡
  • Data Link
    • Activating, Maintaining and Deactivating a Reliable Link â€“ between local devices ğŸ”—
    • Media access control ğŸ›‚
    • Error Detection and Control ğŸ›‘
      • Higher Layers May Assume Error Free Transmission âœ¨

OSI Layers (2)

  • Network
    • Delivery of Information ğŸ“¦
      • logical addressing ğŸ·ï¸
      • routing ğŸ›£ï¸
    • Fragmentation and assembly ğŸ”¨
    • Error handling âŒ
    • Not Needed on Direct Links ğŸš«
  • Transport
    • Reliability control between End Systems (hosts, computers) ğŸ’»
      • In Sequence ğŸ”¢
      • In good flow ğŸŒŠ
      • Error Free ğŸ†“
      • No Losses ğŸ›‘
      • No Duplicates ğŸ”

OSI Layers (3)

  • Session
    • Control of Dialogues Between Processes ğŸ’¬
      • Establish, manage, and terminate dialogues ğŸ› ï¸
  • Presentation
    • Data Formats and Coding ğŸ“Š
    • Data Compression ğŸ“‰
    • Encryption ğŸ”’
  • Application
    • Implement user required functionalities ğŸ§‘â€ğŸ’»
      • Send letters, move files ğŸ“§

The OSI Environment

  • Communications Path ğŸ›¤ï¸
    • point-to-point link â†”ï¸
    • network ğŸŒ

TCP / IP

  • TCP/IP is an Internet Model ğŸŒ
    • TCP = Transmission Control Protocol ğŸ”„
    • IP = Internet Protocol ğŸŒ
    • This model has only 4-layers 4ï¸âƒ£
    • It is simpler and more practical than the 7-layered OSI-Model ğŸ§ 
    • Created by the US Dept of Defense (DoD) ğŸ›ï¸

TCP/IP Model

  • Application Layer
    • Combines all the application-related issues into 1 layer ğŸ”—
      • Includes the Sessions/Presentation layers ğŸ’¬
  • Transport Layer
    • Deals with the QoS and other issues like
      • Reliability, flow control and error correction âš–ï¸
  • Internet Layer
    • Delivery ğŸ“¦
    • Routing ğŸ›£ï¸
  • Network Interface Layer
    • Ensures the physical links ğŸ”Œ

Hybrid

  • Most layers need
    • Message segmentation and aggregation æ¶ˆæ¯åˆ†æ®µå’Œèšåˆ ğŸ§©
    • Some form of Addressing to identify senders and receivers of messages è¯†åˆ« ğŸ·ï¸
    • Multiplexing/Demultiplexing of multiple message streams to optimize channels æœç”¨/è§£å¤ç”¨ï¼Œä¼˜åŒ–ä¿¡é“ ğŸ”„
    • Flow control (fast sender vs. slow receiver) æµé‡æ§åˆ¶ ğŸŒŠ
    • Error controls (detection and correction) é”™è¯¯æ§åˆ¶ ğŸ› ï¸
    • A set of rules for data exchange æ•°æ®äº¤æ¢ ğŸ“œ
    • Routing of messages when there may be several physical paths è·¯ç”±é€‰æ‹© ğŸ›£ï¸

RDMA (Remote Direct Memory Access)

  • TCP/IP suffers from two major problems:
    • consumes significant CPU cycles and memory resources âš™ï¸
    • has large end-to-end latency ğŸ•°ï¸
  • RDMA copies data directly between virtual memory buffers on two different machines ğŸ”€
    • lower latency, higher throughput, and smaller CPU footprint âš¡
    • used in data centers ğŸ¢

Application Layer Protocols - DNS

Application Architectures

  • Application
    • Communicating, distributed processes è¿›è¡Œé€šè®¯çš„åˆ†å¸ƒå¼è¿›ç¨‹
    • Running in network hosts in “user space” è¿è¡Œåœ¨ç½‘ç»œä¸»æœºçš„ â€œç”¨æˆ·ç©ºé—´â€ ä¸­
    • Exchange messages
    • email, file transfer, the Web
  • Application-layer protocols
    • Define messages exchanged by apps and actions taken å®šä¹‰åº”ç”¨ç¨‹åºä¹‹é—´äº¤æ¢çš„æ¶ˆæ¯ä»¥åŠæ‰€é‡‡å–çš„æ“ä½œ
    • User services provided by lower layer protocols ç”±ä¸‹å±‚åè®®æä¾›çš„ç”¨æˆ·æœåŠ¡

DNS

Domain Name System

Problem - how to map host names to IP addresses?

  • DNS
    • a hierarchical, domain-based naming scheme and a distributed database system for implementing this naming scheme
    • application-layer protocol åº”ç”¨å±‚åè®®
    • hostä¸»æœº, routersè·¯ç”±å™¨, name serversåŸŸåæœåŠ¡å™¨ to communicate to resolve names (address/name translation)

Why not centralize DNS?

  • Single point of failure å•ç‚¹æ•…éšœ
  • Traffic volume é€šä¿¡æµé‡è¿‡å¤§
  • Distant centralized database é›†ä¸­å¼æ•°æ®åº“è·ç¦»è¿‡è¿œ
  • Maintenance
  • doesnâ€™t scale!

  • Root name server
    • Top-level Domain (TLD) server
      • Authoritative name server

Root name servers

  • contacted by local name server that can not resolve name
  • root name server
    • contacts authoritative name server if name mapping not known
    • gets mapping
    • returns mapping to local name server
    • 13 root name servers worldwide

TLD and Authoritative Servers

  • Top-level domain (TLD) servers: responsible for com, org, net, edu, etc, and all top-level country domains uk, fr, ca, jp.
    • Network solutions maintains servers for com TLD.
    • Educause for edu TLD.
  • Authoritative DNS servers: organizationâ€™s DNS servers, providing authoritative hostnameä¸»æœºå to IP mappings for organizationâ€™s servers (e.g., Web and mail).
    • Can be maintained by organization or service provider.

Local Name Server

  • Does not strictly belong to hierarchy
  • Each ISP (residential ISP Internet Service Provider, company, university) has one.
    • Also called “default name server”
  • When a host makes a DNS query, query is sent to its local DNS server
    • Acts as a proxy, forwards query into hierarchy å°†æŸ¥è¯¢è¯·æ±‚è½¬å‘åˆ°ï¼ˆDNS çš„ï¼‰å±‚çº§ç»“æ„ä½“ç³»ä¸­
1

nslookup

Applicaiton Layer Protocols - Email

What happens when you hit SEND on your Email?

  • Three major components
    • User Agents
      • “mail reader”
      • composing, editing, reading mail messages
      • outlook
      • outgoing, incoming messages stored on server
    • Mail Servers
      • mailbox contains incoming messages for user
      • message queue of outgoing (to be sent) mail messages
      • SMTP protocol between mail servers to send email messages
        • client: sending mail server
        • “server”: receiving mail server
    • Simple Mail Transfer Protocol: SMTP

Email: SMTP

[RFC 821] Request for Comments

  • uses TCP to reliably transfer email message from client to server, port 25 (587)
  • direct transfer: sending server to receiving server
  • three phases of transfer
    • handshaking (greeting)
    • transfer of messages
    • closure
  • command/response interaction
    • commands: ASCII text
    • response: status code and phrase
Command Description
HELO, EHLO Identifies the client to the server
MAIL Initiates a mail transaction. Includes senderâ€™s email address
RCPT Specifies an individual recipientâ€™s email address. May be used multiple times to specify multiple recipients.
DATA Initiates transfer of mail contents
RSET Resets/aborts the current mail transaction
VRFY, EXPN Verifies the authenticity of an email address
HELP Asks the server to send helpful information to the client
NOOP No operation. Do nothing
QUIT Instructs the server to terminate the connection
Reply Code Description
220 Sent by the server upon acceptance of the initial client connection.
250 Sent after successful completion of a command
354 Send after acceptance of the DATA command to instruct the client to send the email content
221 Sent by the server before it terminates the connection

Interactions in SMTP - 1 

1

telnet owa.win.udel.edu 25

Actor Command Comment
Receiving SMTP Process 220 reply When a TCP connection is opened, the receiver signals that it is ready.
Sending SMTP Process HELO cnn.com Sender asks to begin Sending a message. Gives own identity.
Receiver 250 reply Receiver signals that it is ready to begin Receiving a message.

    è®°å¿†ç‚¹ï¼šâ€œç”µè¯æ¥é€šï¼Œå¯¹æ–¹è¯´å‡†å¤‡å¥½â€
  • è¿˜æ˜¯æ‰“ç”µè¯åœºæ™¯ï¼Œä½ å…ˆè·Ÿæœ‹å‹è‡ªæŠ¥å®¶é—¨ â€œæˆ‘æ˜¯ [ä½ çš„åå­—]â€ï¼ˆå¯¹åº”å‘é€ SMTP è¿›ç¨‹å‘é€ HELOÂ cnn.comÂ ï¼Œå‘ŠçŸ¥è‡ªå·±èº«ä»½ï¼‰ï¼Œç„¶åè¯´ â€œæˆ‘æœ‰äº‹å„¿è¦è·Ÿä½ è®²å“¦â€ï¼ˆå¯¹åº”å‘é€æ–¹è¯·æ±‚å¼€å§‹å‘é€æ¶ˆæ¯ï¼‰ã€‚
    è®°å¿†ç‚¹ï¼šâ€œè‡ªæŠ¥å®¶é—¨ï¼Œè¯´è¦è®²è¯â€
  • ä½ æœ‹å‹å¬åˆ°ä½ è¦è®²è¯åï¼Œè¯´ â€œå¥½å‘€ï¼Œä½ è¯´å§â€ï¼ˆå¯¹åº”æ¥æ”¶æ–¹å‘é€ 250 å›å¤ï¼‰ï¼Œæ„æ€å°±æ˜¯å‡†å¤‡å¥½æ¥æ”¶ä½ è¯´çš„äº‹å„¿å•¦ï¼ˆå¯¹åº”æ¥æ”¶æ–¹å‡†å¤‡å¥½æ¥æ”¶æ¶ˆæ¯ï¼‰ã€‚
    è®°å¿†ç‚¹ï¼šâ€œå¯¹æ–¹å›åº”ï¼Œå‡†å¤‡å€¾å¬â€

Interactions in SMTP - 2

Actor Command Comment
Sender MAIL FROM: aha@cnn.com Sender identifies the sender (mail author, not SMTP process).
Receiver 250 OK Accepts author. However, May reject mail from others.
Sender RCPT TO: jcao@udel.edu Identifies first mail recipient.
Receiver 250 OK Accepts first recipient
  • ç¬¬ä¸€æ­¥: “Sender”ï¼ˆå‘é€æ–¹ï¼‰å‘å‡º “MAIL FROM: aha@cnn.com” çš„æŒ‡ä»¤ï¼Œå°±æ˜¯å‘Šè¯‰æ¥æ”¶æ–¹è¿™å°é‚®ä»¶æ˜¯è°å†™çš„ï¼ˆå‘ä»¶äººé‚®ç®±æ˜¯ aha@cnn.com ï¼‰
  • ç¬¬äºŒæ­¥: “Receiver”ï¼ˆæ¥æ”¶æ–¹ï¼‰å›å¤ “250 OK”ï¼Œæ„æ€æ˜¯æ¥æ”¶æ–¹è®¤å¯äº†è¿™ä¸ªå‘ä»¶äººï¼Œä½†å¯èƒ½ä¸æ¥å—å…¶ä»–å‘ä»¶äººçš„é‚®ä»¶
  • ç¬¬ä¸‰æ­¥ï¼šå‘é€æ–¹åˆå‘å‡º “RCPT TO: jcao@udel.edu” çš„æŒ‡ä»¤ï¼Œè¡¨æ˜è¿™å°é‚®ä»¶ç¬¬ä¸€ä¸ªæ”¶ä»¶äººçš„é‚®ç®±æ˜¯ jcao@udel.edu
  • ç¬¬å››æ­¥ï¼šæ¥æ”¶æ–¹å†æ¬¡å›å¤ “250 OK”ï¼Œè¡¨ç¤ºæ¥å—è¿™ä¸ªæ”¶ä»¶äºº

Interactionis in SMTP - 3

Actor Command Comment
Sender DATA
Receiver 354 Enter mail, end with "." on a line by itself
Sender Blah blah blah ...
Receiver 250 Message accepted for delivery
  • å‡†å¤‡å‘é€å†…å®¹ï¼šå‘é€æ–¹ï¼ˆSenderï¼‰å‘å‡º “DATA” æŒ‡ä»¤ï¼Œå‘Šè¯‰æ¥æ”¶æ–¹è¦å¼€å§‹å‘é€é‚®ä»¶å†…å®¹äº†
  • æ¥æ”¶æ–¹æŒ‡ç¤ºï¼šæ¥æ”¶æ–¹ï¼ˆReceiverï¼‰å›å¤ “354 Enter mail, end with “.” on a line by itself”ï¼Œæ„æ€æ˜¯è®©å‘é€æ–¹å¼€å§‹è¾“å…¥é‚®ä»¶å†…å®¹ï¼Œå¹¶ä¸”è¦ä»¥å•ç‹¬ä¸€è¡Œçš„ç‚¹ï¼ˆ.ï¼‰ä½œä¸ºå†…å®¹ç»“æŸçš„æ ‡å¿—
  • å‘é€å®é™…å†…å®¹ï¼šå‘é€æ–¹å¼€å§‹å‘é€å…·ä½“çš„é‚®ä»¶å†…å®¹ï¼Œè¿™é‡Œç”¨ “Blah blah blah …” ä»£è¡¨å†…å®¹ï¼Œç„¶åç”¨å•ç‹¬çš„ä¸€ä¸ªç‚¹ï¼ˆ.ï¼‰è¡¨æ˜å†…å®¹å‘é€å®Œæ¯•
  • æ¥æ”¶ç¡®è®¤ï¼šæ¥æ”¶æ–¹è¿”å› “250 Message accepted for delivery”ï¼Œè¡¨ç¤ºå·²ç»æˆåŠŸæ¥æ”¶é‚®ä»¶å†…å®¹ï¼Œä¼šè¿›è¡Œåç»­çš„æŠ•é€’æ“ä½œ

Interactions in SMTP - 4

Actor Command Comment
Sender QUIT
Receiver 221 md1.nss.udel.edu closing connection
- å‘é€æ–¹ï¼ˆSenderï¼‰å‘å‡º "QUIT" æŒ‡ä»¤ï¼Œè¡¨ç¤ºè¦ç»“æŸä¸æ¥æ”¶æ–¹çš„è¿æ¥ - æ¥æ”¶æ–¹ï¼ˆReceiverï¼‰å›å¤ "221 md1.nss.udel.edu closing connection"ï¼Œè¯´æ˜æ¥æ”¶æ–¹å‡†å¤‡å…³é—­è¿æ¥ï¼Œ"md1.nss.udel.edu" æ˜¯æ¥æ”¶æ–¹æœåŠ¡å™¨æ ‡è¯†

SMTP Security Issues

  • No authenticationï¼šæ— èº«ä»½éªŒè¯
  • Spammingï¼šåƒåœ¾é‚®ä»¶å‘é€
  • Unauthorized use of relaying, DoSï¼šæœªç»æˆæƒä½¿ç”¨é‚®ä»¶ä¸­ç»§ã€æ‹’ç»æœåŠ¡æ”»å‡»
  • All communication done in plaintextï¼šæ‰€æœ‰é€šä¿¡å‡ä»¥æ˜æ–‡å½¢å¼è¿›è¡Œ
  • Eavesdroppingï¼šçªƒå¬
  • Man in the middle attacksï¼šä¸­é—´äººæ”»å‡»

SMTP-AUTH

  • An extension that adds access control to SMTP.

  • Allows the server to provide features only to known users and limit others.

  • The default port for SMTP AUTH is 587.

  • Various authentication methods can be used, such as PLAIN, LOGIN, CRAM - MD5, etc.

  • Encryption is highly recommended. å¼ºçƒˆå»ºè®®ä½¿ç”¨åŠ å¯†åŠŸèƒ½

  • PLAIN

    • The username and password are transmitted as one string encoded in Base64.

  • LOGIN

    • The username and password are encoded in Base64 and transmitted one by one, first the username and then the password.

  • CRAM - MD5

    • The server requests the client to solve a computational challenge using the password.
    • The client’s response is a string containing a username and a 16 - byte digest in hexadecimal notation.
    • This string is BASE64 - encoded.

Mail message format

  • SMTP [RFC 821]: protocol for exchanging email message

  • RFC 822: standard for text message

  • header lines

    • To:
    • From:
    • Subject:

  • different from SMTP commands

  • body

    • the “message”, ASCII characters only

  • MIME: multimedia mail extension, RFC 2045, 2056

  • additional lines in message header declare MIME content type

Scenario: Alice sends message to Bob

  1. Alice uses her User Agent (UA) to compose a message and sets the “to” field as “bob@someschool.edu”.
  2. Alice’s UA sends the message to her mail server, and the message is placed in the message queue.
  3. The client - side of SMTP opens a TCP connection with Bob’s mail server.
    User Agent - Mail Server
  4. The SMTP client sends Alice’s message over the TCP connection.
  5. Bob’s mail server places the message in Bob’s mailbox.
  6. Bob invokes his User Agent to read the message.
  • SMTP (Simple Mail Transfer Protocol)
    • deliver and store emails to the recipient’s server.
  • Email Access Protocols: retrieval from server
    • POP (Post Office Protocol, based on RFC 1939 standard)
      • authorization process between the user agent and the server to achieve the function of downloading emails.
    • IMAP (Internet Mail Access Protocol, based on RFC 1730 standard)
      • more features (more complex).
      • manipulation of stored msgs on server
    • HTTP
      • Hotmail, Yahoo!Mail

POP3

  • “download and delete” mode
    • You cannot re-read e mail if you changes client
  • “download-and keep” mode
    • copies of messages on different clients
  • POP3 is stateless across sessions

IMAP

  • Keep all messages in one place: the server.
  • Allow users to organize messages in folders.
  • IMAP maintains the user state across sessions:
    • names of folders and the mappings between message IDs and folders.

Application Layer Protocols - HTTP

Web and HTTP

  • First, some jargon:

    • A web page consists of objects.
    • An object can be an HTML file, a JPEG image, a Java applet, an audio file, etc.
    • A web page consists of a base HTML file which includes several referenced objects.
    • Each object is addressable by a URL.
    • Example URL:

  • HTTP: hypertext transfer protocol

  • Webâ€™s application layer protocol

  • client/server model

    • client: browser that requests, receives, “displays” Web objects
    • server: Web server sends objects in response to requests

  • HTTP 1.0: RFC 1945

  • HTTP 1.1: RFC 2068

HTTP request message

  • two types of HTTP messages: request, response
  • HTTP request message: ASCII (human-readable format)
  • general format

Method types

  • HTTP/1.1
    • GET
    • POST
    • HEAD
    • PUT
      • uploads file in entity body to path specified in URL field
    • DELETE
      • asks server to leave requested object out of response
      • deletes file specified in the URL field
  • HTTP/1.0
    • GET, POST, HEAD

Uploading from input

  • Post method:
    • Web page often includes form input
    • Input is uploaded to server in entity body
  • URL method:
    • Uses GET method
    • Input is uploaded in URL field of request line

HTTP response message

  • In first line in server->client response message.
  • A few sample codes:
    • 200 OK
      • request succeeded, requested object later in this message
    • 301 Moved Permanently
      • requested object moved, new location specified later in this message (Location:)
    • 400 Bad Request
      • request message not understood by server
    • 404 Not Found
      • requested document not found on this server
    • 505 HTTP Version Not Supported

HTTP/2

  • HTTP/2 specification was published as RFC 7540 in May 2015.
  • HTTP/2 allows the server to “push” content, that is, to respond with data for more queries than the client requested.
  • Multiplexing of requests, header compression, and prioritization of request. First draft was published in 2020

HTTP/3

  • First draft was published in 2020
  • Uses QUIC (Quick UDP Internet Connections) as the transport layer protocol
  • Encrypted connections
    • Like always employing HTTPS in current HTTP 2.0
  • HTTP/1 to HTTP/2 to HTTP/3

Try out HTTP (client side)

  1. Telnet to your favorite Web server:
1

telnet udel.edu 80
  1. Type in a GET HTTP request:
1
2

GET /~jcao/ HTTP/1.1 
Host: udel.edu
  1. Look at response message sent by HTTP server!
    Downloading a Complex Webpage with Two Graphics Files

Transport Layer Protocols - TCP and UDP

Sockets and Port Number

socket å¥—æ¥å­—

  • Application process sends/receives messages to/from its socket åº”ç”¨ç¨‹åºé€šè¿‡socketå‘é€æˆ–æ¥æ”¶ä¿¡æ¯
  • socket analogous to door socket ç±»ä¼¼äºä¸€æ‰‡é—¨
    • sending process shoves message out door å‘é€è¿›ç¨‹å°±åƒæ˜¯æŠŠæ¶ˆæ¯æ¨å‡ºé—¨
    • sending process relies on transport infrastructure on other side of door which brings message to socket at receiving process å‘é€è¿›ç¨‹ä¾èµ–äºå¦ä¸€ç«¯çš„ä¼ è¾“åŸºç¡€è®¾æ–½ï¼Œå°†æ¶ˆæ¯ä¼ é€’åˆ°æ¥æ”¶è¿›ç¨‹çš„å¥—æ¥å­—
  • API:
    • (1) choice of transport protocol;
    • (2) ability to fix a few parameters

  • Addressing processes

    • identifier of a process includes both IP addresses and port numbers associated with the process on hosts.
    • Example port numbers:
      • HTTP server: 80
      • Mail server: 25
    • to send HTTP message to gaia.cs.umass.edu web server:
      • IP address: 128.119.245.12
      • Port number: 80

  • Use of Port Numbers

    • Well-known port numbers are 0 to 1023. These are used by popular applications.
    • Servers/daemons usually use well-known ports.
      • Any client can identify the server/service.
    • Registered port numbers (1024 to 49152)
      • used for less central applications.
      • http://www.iana.org/assignments/port-numbers
    • Ephemeral port numbers: 49153 to 65535
      • Clients usually use dynamic ports.
      • Assigned by the client kernel at run time.
      • Traditionally (including Windows systems) take the range of 1024 through 4999
Socket = IP Address:Port Number

Transport Layer Protocols

  • provide logical communication between application processes running on different hosts

  • transport protocols run in end systems

    • sender side: breaks app messages into segments, passes to network layer
    • receiver side: reassembles segments into messages, passes to app layer

  • more than one transport protocol available to apps

    • Internet: TCP and UDP

  • Transmission Control Protocol (TCP)

    • Connection-oriented; reliable, in-order delivery
    • Reliable data transfer
    • Flow control
    • Congestion control

  • User Datagram Protocol (UDP)

    • Connectionless â€“ unreliable, unordered delivery

  • TCP: Overview

    • point-to-point
      • one sender, one receiver
    • reliable, in-order byte stream
      • no â€œmessage boundariesâ€
    • send & receive buffers
    • connection-orinted
      • handshaking (exchange of control msgs) before data exchange
    • flow controlled
      • sender will not overwhelm receiver
        • set window size

Transmission Control Protocol (TCP)

  • TCP Segment Format
  • 32 bit sequence numbers
  • TCP breaks byte stream from application into segments (limited by Max. Segment Size)
    • Each segment has a sequence number
    • Initial number selected at connection time
  • Subsequent numbers indicate first data byte number in segment

Acknowledgetments (ACK)

  • ACK# indicates next data byte expected

    • Next sequence # from the other side

  • Used for Error Control

    • Each correct TCP segment is acknowledged, except for pure acknowledgements and resets
    • Sender listens to be sure that each TCP segment is acknowledged
    • If a segment is not acknowledged in a reasonable period of time, the sender resends it

  • TCP Connection Management 3-Way Handshake

  • TCP Flow Control
  • Flow Control
    • One TCP process transmits too fast
    • Other TCP process is overwhelmed
    • Receiver must control transmission rate
    • This is flow control
  • TCP segment has a Window Size
    • Tell how many more bytes the sender can send beyond the segment being acknowledged
  • Example
    • TCP segment contained bytes 45-89
    • Acknowledgement number for TCP segment acknowledging the segment is 90
    • If Window Size field value is 50, then
      • Sender may send through byte 140
      • Must then stop unless the window has been extended in another acknowledgement
  • Each Acknowledgement extends the window of bytes that may be sent
    • Called a sliding window protocol

User Datagram Protocol (UDP)

TCP vs. UDP

UDP

  • Connectionless and Unreliable
  • Places a Lighter Load on the Network than TCP
  • Useful Where the Loss of an Occasional Application Message is Not a Serious Problem
  • As in Regular Network Status Messages
  • Or Where There is No Time for Retransmission, As in Voice Transmission

Lab 1 - Introduction to Wireshark

Encapsulation

Packet Sniffing

  • With a packet sniffer, get the ability to capture the data and look inside the packets to see what is actually moving long the tracks.
  • Sometimes referred to as Network Monitoring Tools
  • Can be used legitimately by network and system administrators to verify network traffic and diagnose problems
  • Can be used to determine what systems and protocols are unprotected/unencrypted in a network and take action (good/bad)
  • Can be used to obtain critical information (passwords, cc numbers; anything unencrypted that is transmitted over the network) by malicious hackers

Tools

  • Wireshark

Display Filter

  • Note the box at the top of Wireshark for display filters
  • Select only some of the packets captured for display
  • The comparison operators can be expressed either through C-like symbols, or through English-like abbreviations:
1
2
3
4
5
6

eq, == Equal
ne, != Not equal
gt, > Greater than 
lt, < Less Than
ge, >= Greater than or Equal to 
le, <= Less than or Equal to

Advanced Filtering

  • Filter for just that stream
1
2

(ip.addr eq 207.46.133.140 and ip.addr eq 172.17.22.56) and
(tcp.port eq 21 and tcp.port eq 3511)
  • Filter for traffic between two hosts
1

ip.addr == 207.46.133.140 and ip.addr == 172.17.22.56
  • Filter for IP Traffic and removal of other traffic
1

ip and !(nbns) and !(msnms) and !(browser) and !(rip)

Capture Filters

  • The capture filter syntax follows the rules of the pcap library
  • This syntax is different from the display filter syntax
  • Sample filters
1
2

src ip 192.168.1.1
ether src 00:50:BA:48:B5:EF
  • A capture filter for HTTP that captures traffic to and from a particular host
1

tcp port 80 and host 10.10.10.5
  • A capture filter for HTTP that captures traffic not from a particular host
1

tcp port 80 and not host 10.10.10.5
  • A capture filter to and from an ethernet address
1

ether 00:00:01:01:02:22

Network Layer Protocols - IP Address

Network layer

  • moving data across a series of interconnected networks
  • transport segment from sending to receiving host ä¼ è¾“æ•°æ®æ®µä»å‘é€ä¸»æœºåˆ°æ¥æ”¶ä¸»æœº æ‰¾åˆ°åˆé€‚çš„è·¯å¾„ä¼ é€
  • on sending side encapsulates segments into packets (or datagrams)
  • on receiving side delivers segments to transport layer
  • network layer protocols in every host, router
  • Router examines header fields in all IP datagrams passing through it

Two Key Network-Layer Functions

  • routing: determine route taken by packets from source to destination
    • routing algorithms
  • forwarding: move packets from routerâ€™s input to appropriate router output

  • The Internet Protocol
    • Packets, addressing and routing
    • Two types: IPv4 and IPv6

Versions of IP

  • IP - Internet Protocol
  • Defined in RFC 791, dated 1981, written by information Sciences Institute @ USC
  • Written for DARPA (Defense Advanced Research Projects Agency)
  • IPv0 - 3: Experimental Only
  • IPv4: Defined in 1981 by RFC 760 & 791.Â  First version to implemented publically.Â  Still in use today
  • IPv5: Also experimental, called Internet Stream Protocol
  • IPv6: Also called IP Next Generation (IPng), Defined in 1998 by RFC 2460-2467

IP Addresses: IPv4 vs IPv6

IPv4 IPv6
Deployed 1981 Deployed 1999
32-bit address 128-bit address
192.149.252.76 2001:DB8:0234:AB00:0123:4567:8901:ABCD
Address space $$2^{32} \approx 4,000,000,000$$ Address space $$2^{128} \approx 340,000,000,000,000,000,000,000,000,000,000,000,000$$
Security, autoconfig, QoS, mobility added later (IPSec etc) Security, autoconfig, QoS â€œbuilt-inâ€
Projected lifetime: 2012 Projected lifetime: Indefinite

IPv4 Exhaustion

IPv4åœ°å€è€—å°½

  • IANA doles out IPv4 blocks to the regional providers

IPv4 Packer vs. IPv6 Packer

  • Romoved (6)
    • ID, flags, flag offset
    • TOS, hlen
    • header, checksum
  • Changed (3)
    • total length => played
    • protocol => next header
    • TTL => hop limit
  • Added (2)
    • traffic class
    • flow label
  • Expanded
    • address 32 to 128 bits

Major Improvements of IPv6 Header

  • No option field é€‰é¡¹å­—æ®µ
    • Replaced by extension header æ‰©å±•å¤´.Â  Result in a fixed length, 40-byte IP header
  • No header checksum æ²¡æœ‰å¤´éƒ¨æ ¡éªŒå’Œ
    • Result in fast processing
  • No fragmentation at intermediate nodes ä¸­é—´èŠ‚ç‚¹ä¸ç”¨åˆ†æ®µ
    • Result in fast IP forwarding

IPv4 Addressing

  • interface: connection between host/router and physical link
    • routers typically have multiple interfaces è·¯ç”±å™¨æœ‰å¤šä¸ªæ¥å£
    • host typically has one interface ä¸»æœºåªæœ‰ä¸€ä¸ªæ¥å£
    • IP addresses associated with each interface
  • IP address: 32-bit identifier for host, router interface

IP Address

  • 32 binary numbers (bits)
  • dotted decimal notation (xxx.xxx.xxx.xxx)
    • Each decimal number represents eight bits (one octet) of binary data
    • 0 ~ 255 $(2^{8}-1)$

      E.g. 128.196.205.27 to Binary 10000000 11000100 11001101 00011011

IP addresses: how to get one?

  • DHCP: Dynamic Host Configuration Protocol åŠ¨æ€ä¸»æœºé…ç½®åè®®
    • dynamically get address from as server
    • “plug-and-play”
  • Hard-coded by system admin in a file ç³»ç»Ÿç®¡ç†å‘˜æ‰‹åŠ¨è®¾ç½®
    • Wintel: network -> properties -> IP Settings
    • UNIX: /etc/rc.config
1

Command line utility: ipconfig

Division b/w Network ID & Host ID

  • Unique address
    • Network ID assigned globally
      • IANA (Internet Assigned Numbers Authority) äº’è”ç½‘å·ç åˆ†é…æœºæ„
    • Host ID assigned locally
  • How many bits for Network and for Host?
    • Where is that “dividing line”?
  • Types of addrssing
    • “Classful” æœ‰ç±»ç¼–å€
      • Divide on octet boundaries å…«å­—èŠ‚
    • Subnetted “Classful” å­ç½‘åˆ’åˆ†çš„æœ‰ç±»ç¼–åˆ¶
      • Use a subnet mask
    • Classless
      • Indicated by the prefix length

IP Address Classes

  • Originally (before 1993), IP had address classes with fixed numbers of bits in the network part
    • Class A: 8 bits (24 bits in host part)
    • Class B: 16 bits (16 bits in host part)
    • Class C: 24 bits (8 bits in host part)
  • Self-encoded: è‡ªæˆ‘ç¼–ç ç‰¹æ€§
    • The router looks at the first few bits of the IP address, and then will be able to decide where to draw the line
  • Another way to determine the address class is by looking at the first number in the dotted decimal notation

    How can we recognize to which class an IP address belongs to?

    Look at the first 4 bits!

    Another way to determine the address class is by looking at the first number in the dotted decimal notation

Class Range of Values
A 0 through 127
B 128 through 191
C 192 through 223
D 224 through 239
E 240 through 255

Network Address Translation

  • Each organization- single IP address
  • Within organization â€“ each host with IP unique to the organization, from reserved set of IP addresses å†…éƒ¨è®¾å¤‡ç”¨ç»„ç»‡å†…ç‹¬æœ‰çš„IPåœ°å€
Reserved Range Address Range Number of Hosts
First 10.0.0.0 â€“ 10.255.255.255 16,777,216
Second 172.16.0.0 â€“ 172.31.255.255/12 1,048,576
Third 192.168.0.0 â€“ 192.168.255.255/16 65,536

Network Layer Protocols - IP Subnetting

CIDR

Classless Inter Domain Routing æ— ç±»åˆ«åŸŸé—´è·¯ç”±

  • network portion of address of arbitrary length
  • address format: a.b.c.d/x, where x is # bits in network portion of address

  • Efficient Allocation of Addresses
    • Subnetting
      • division of networks into smaller units
    • Supernetting
      • combination of smaller networks into larger ones
        • E.g. allows the aggregation of contiguous blocks of Class-C addresses into larger networks
  • CIDR-capable routers explicitly store the network masks (prefix length) in the router

Subnetting

  • Split the host number portion of an IP address into a subnet number and a (smaller) host number

Subnet Mask

  • Routers and hosts uses an extended network prefix (subnet mask) to identify the start of the host numbers
  • Subnet Mask
    • 1s in the subnet parts
    • 0s in the remaining bits

With Subnetting

  • Hosts with same extended network prefix belong to the same hostwork

IP Address and Network Capacities

  • IP address: 32-bit identifier for host, router interface
    • X bits for the network part
    • Y bits for the host part
  • $of\quad possible\quad networks = 2^X$
  • $of\quad possible\quad hosts\quad in\quad each\quad network = 2^Y -2$
    • “all 0s” - this network
    • “all 1s - broadcasting
  • We can manipulate our subnet mask in order to create more network addresses

Example

  • We were given a 206.15.143.0/24 block from our ISP for our network
    • This gives us 1 Network (206.15.143.0) with the potential for 254 host addresses (206.15.143.1 to 206.15.143.254)
  • But we have a LAN made up of 5 sub-networks with the largest one serving 25 hosts
    • So we need to Subnet
    • We need at least 5 subnets
      • $2^3$ will give us 8 subnet addresses
    • We need at least 25 housts per network
      • $2^5-2$ will give us 30 hosts per subnet
    • This will work!
      • steal the first 3 bits from the hostâ€™s portion of the address to give to the subnet portion
        • extended-network-prefix is /27
      • still have 5 (8-3) left for the host portion
